author.affiliation: California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA 91125

abstract.p: We propose a mechanism for stabilizing the size of the extra dimension in the Randall-Sundrum scenario. The potential for the modulus field that sets the size of the fifth dimension is generated by a bulk scalar with quartic interactions localized on the two 3-branes. The minimum of this potential yields a compactification scale that solves the hierarchy problem without fine tuning of parameters.

body.p: The Standard Model for strong, weak, and electromagnetic interactions based on the gauge group Sâ¢Uâ¢(3)Ã—Sâ¢Uâ¢(2)Ã—Uâ¢(1)ğ‘†ğ‘ˆ3ğ‘†ğ‘ˆ2ğ‘ˆ1 has been extremely succesful in accounting for experimental observations. However, it has several unattractive features that suggest new physics beyond that incorporated in this model. One of these is the gauge hierarchy problem, which refers to the vast disparity between the weak scale and the Planck scale. In the context of the minimal Standard Model, this hierarchy of scales is unnatural since it requires a fine tuning order by order in perturbation theory. A number of extensions have been proposed to solve the hierarchy problem, notably technicolor(1) (or dynamical symmetry breaking) and low energy supersymmetry(2).

Recently, it has been suggested that large compactified extra dimensions may provide an alternative solution to the hierarchy problem(3). In these models, the observed Planck mass MPâ¢lsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘ƒğ‘™ is related to M,ğ‘€ the fundamental mass scale of the theory, by MPâ¢l2=Mn+2â¢Vn,superscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘ƒğ‘™2superscriptğ‘€ğ‘›2subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘› where Vnsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘› is the volume of the additional compactified dimensions. If Vnsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘› is large enough, Mğ‘€ can be of the order of the weak scale. Unfortunately, unless there are several large extra dimensions, a new hierarchy is introduced between the compactification scale, Î¼c=Vn-1/n,subscriptğœ‡ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘›1ğ‘› and M.ğ‘€

Randall and Sundrum (4) have proposed a higher dimensional scenario to solve the hierachy problem that does not require large extra dimensions. This model consists of a spacetime with a single S1/Z2superscriptğ‘†1subscriptğ‘2 orbifold extra dimension. Three-branes with opposite tensions reside at the orbifold fixed points and together with a finely tuned cosmological constant serve as sources for five-dimensional gravity. The resulting spacetime metric contains a redshift factor which depends exponentially on the radius rcsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘ of the compactified dimension:

where kğ‘˜ is a parameter which is assumed to be of order Mğ‘€, xÎ¼superscriptğ‘¥ğœ‡ are Lorentz coordinates on the four-dimensional surfaces of constant Ï•italic-Ï•, and -Ï€â‰¤Ï•â‰¤Ï€ğœ‹italic-Ï•ğœ‹ with (x,Ï•)ğ‘¥italic-Ï• and (x,-Ï•)ğ‘¥italic-Ï• identified. The two 3-branes are located at Ï•=0italic-Ï•0 and Ï•=Ï€.italic-Ï•ğœ‹ A similar scenario to the one described in ref. (4) is that of Horava and Witten (5), which arises within the context of Mğ‘€-theory. Supergravity solutions similar to Eq. (1) are presented in ref. (6). In ref. (7), it is shown how this model may be obtained from string theory compactifications.
The non-factorizable geometry of Eq. (1) has several important consequences. For instance, the four-dimensional Planck mass is given in terms of the fundamental scale Mğ‘€ by

so that, even for large kâ¢rc,ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘MPâ¢lsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘ƒğ‘™ is of order M.ğ‘€ Because of the exponential factor in the spacetime metric, a field confined to the 3-brane at Ï•=Ï€italic-Ï•ğœ‹ with mass parameter m0subscriptğ‘š0 will have physical mass m0â¢e-kâ¢rcâ¢Ï€subscriptğ‘š0superscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘ğœ‹ and for kâ¢rcğ‘˜subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘ around 12, the weak scale is dynamically generated from a fundamental scale Mğ‘€ which is on the order of the Planck mass. Furthermore, Kaluza-Klein gravitational modes have TeV scale mass splittings and couplings(8). Similarly, a bulk field with mass on the order of Mğ‘€ has low-lying Kaluza-Klein excitations that reside primarily near Ï•=Ï€italic-Ï•ğœ‹ and hence, from a four-dimensional perspective, have masses on the order of the weak scale (9).

In the scenario presented in ref. (4), rcsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘ is associated with the vacuum expectation value of a massless four-dimensional scalar field. This modulus field has zero potential and consequently rcsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘ is not determined by the dynamics of the model. For this scenario to be relevant, it is necessary to find a mechanism for generating a potential to stabilize the value of rc.subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘ Here we show that such a potential can arise classically from the presence of a bulk scalar with interaction terms that are localized to the two 3-branes
Other proposals for stabilizing the rcsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘ modulus can be found in ref. (10).. The minimum of this potential can be arranged to yield a value of kâ¢rcâˆ¼10similar-toğ‘˜subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘10 without fine tuning of parameters.

One might worry that the validity of Eq. (13) and Eq. (14) requires unnaturally large values of Î»hsubscriptğœ†â„ and Î»vsubscriptğœ†ğ‘£. We will check that this is not the case by computing the leading 1/Î»1ğœ† correction to the potential. To obtain this correction, we linearize Eq. (9) and Eq. (10) about the large Î»ğœ† solution. In the scenario of Randall and Sundrum, the action is the sum of the five-dimensional Einstein-Hilbert action plus world-volume actions for the 3-branes:

For Eq. (1) to be a solution of the field equations that follow from Eq. (26), one must arrange Vh=-Vv=24â¢M3â¢k,subscriptğ‘‰â„subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘£24superscriptğ‘€3ğ‘˜ where Î›=-24â¢M3â¢k2Î›24superscriptğ‘€3superscriptğ‘˜2. This amounts to having a vanishing four-dimensional cosmological constant plus an additional fine tuning which causes the rcsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘ potential to vanish. However, imagine perturbing the 3-brane tensions by small amounts
It has been noted that given the action in Eq. (26), changes in the relation between the brane tensions and the bulk cosmological constant result in bent brane solutions(11). It is possible that there are higher dimension induced curvature terms in the brane actions that make it energetically favorable for them to stay flat. For Vh=-Vv=24â¢M3â¢k,subscriptğ‘‰â„subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘£24superscriptğ‘€3ğ‘˜ Eq. (1) remains a solution to the field equations in the presence of such terms.:

For Î´â¢Vvğ›¿subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘£ small, the sum of potentials VÎ¦â¢(rc)+VÎ›â¢(rc)subscriptğ‘‰Î¦subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘subscriptğ‘‰Î›subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘ has a minimum for large kâ¢rc.ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘ The effective four-dimensional cosmological constant can be tuned to zero by adjusting the value of Î´â¢Vh.ğ›¿subscriptğ‘‰â„ For Î´â¢Vv<kâ¢Ïµâ¢vv2ğ›¿subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘£ğ‘˜italic-Ïµsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘£2 the minimum is global, while for Î´â¢Vv>kâ¢Ïµâ¢vv2ğ›¿subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘£ğ‘˜italic-Ïµsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘£2 the minimum is a false vacuum since rcâ†’âˆâ†’subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘ is a configuration of lower energy.

We have seen that a bulk scalar with a Ï•italic-Ï•-dependent VEV can generate a potential to stabilize rcsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘ without having to fine tune the parameters of the model (there is still one fine tuning associated with the four-dimensional cosmological constant, however). This mechanism for stabilizing rcsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘ is a reasonably generic effect caused by the presence of a Ï•italic-Ï•-dependent vacuum bulk field configuration. It may be worthwile to work out other features of the specific toy model presented here, such as the back reaction of the scalar field and shifts of the brane tensions on the spacetime geometry. Also, the use of the large Î»ğœ† limit was purely for convenience and the finite Î»ğœ† case could be considered.

With rcsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘ stabilized, the cosmology associated with this scenario should be standard for temperatures below the weak scale. However, for temperatures above this scale, it will be different (see ref. (12)) from the usual Friedmann cosmology.

The scenario presented in ref. (4) represents an attractive solution to the hierarchy puzzle. However, it also has some features that are less appealing than the Standard Model with minimal particle content. In this scenario, higher dimension operators are suppressed by the weak scale and unlike the Standard Model, where the suppression can be by powers of the GUT scale, there is no explanation for the smallness of neutrino masses and the long proton lifetime based simply on dimensional analysis.
We thank R. Sundrum for several useful conversations. This work was supported in part by the Department of Energy under grant number DE-FG03-92-ER 40701.
